Confirm The 17th Century The 18th Century The 19th Century Turn of the Century Remembrance & WW1 WW2 & Post War Conflicts Eaton Hall: Eaton Hall sits in the Cheshire countryside about 5 miles from Chester and is the home of the Duke of Westminster. At the beginning of World War II, the second Duke vacated his house to help with the war effort. From 1943 until September 1946, it was home to the Britannia Royal Naval College, which had been forced to leave the exposed position in Dartmouth. In 1946, it passed to the army and was used until 1958 as a training centre for National Service Officer Cadets. The Eaton Hall Officer Cadets were put through a 16-week course. Some 15,000 men were trained there, and many went straight into operational duty in Malaya, Korea and other trouble spots of the post war era." The Cheshire Regiment The Cheshire Regiment was raised on the Roodee in 1689. In 1743, it won the distinction of wearing the oak leaf from George II at Dettingen ‚Äì still part of its badge today. In the 18th Century, its most famous achievement was the taking of Louisburg in Nova Scotia, after which the Grenadier Company went on with General Wolfe to Quebec. After the Seven Years War, the Regiment spent time in the West Indies and then took part in the American War of Independence In the 1840s, the 22nd was part of Sir Charles Napier‚Äôs force, when he conquered the Scinde. The battle of Meeanee on the 17th February 1843 is celebrated as the Regimental Day. In the First World War, 38 Battalions were raised by the Cheshires. The 1st Battalion\'s heroic stand near Mons in 1914 saved the British Expeditionary Force from disaster. They went on to be involved in every major action in France and won 35 battle honours. The Territorial and New Army Battalions fought in 6 arenas of war, The 12th Battalion won the French Croix de Guerre, and in total over 8,000 officers and men gave their lives. Throughout the Second World War, the Cheshire‚Äôs were armed with the Vickers machine gun and acted as a Support Regiment. The 2nd Battalion were at Dunkirk, and in North Africa and Italy, before returning to be part of the initial landings and Normandy. The 1st fought in North Africa and were in Malta during the siege. The 6th and 7th Battalions after Dunkirk fought in North Africa and Italy with distinction. Since the war, the 1st Battalion has served in numerous operational areas including Malaya, Cyprus and Northern Ireland and recently in Bosnia under the United Nations. The Cheshire Yeomanry The Cheshire Yeomanry was raised by Sir John Fleming Leicester of Tabley in 1797 when Britain was under threat from Napoleon. Initially there were 6 troops of cavalry made up from local gentry farmers who brought their own horses. In 1803 the Regiment was granted the title of The Earl of Chester‚Äôs Regiment of Yeomanry and with it the right to wear the Price of Wales‚Äôs feathers. The first call out was in August 1819 when there were riots in St Peter‚Äôs Field, Manchester (Peterloo). They were congratulated for their ‚Äúsoldier like conduct‚Äù which was ‚Äúgentle and right‚Äù. During the 19th Century, they were often called out ‚Äúin aid of the civil power‚Äù and first went on active service abroad in 1900 in the Boer War. In 1914 the Regiment was mobilised and fought the Turks in Palestine in 1916 as infantry. Later they were posted to France in 1918 and fought in the final stages of the First World War in their infantry role. Between the wars, it re-formed as mounted cavalry and took its horses on an epic journey by train and boat to Palestine, taking part in Syria in the last cavalry action of the British Army. In 1942 it became a Royal Signals Regiment and then in 1947 an armoured regiment. In 1968 it underwent considerable change during reorganisation of the Territorial Army. It became part of The Queen‚Äôs own Yeomanry in 1971 and today it is based in Chester as C Squadron of the Royal Mercian and Lancastrian Yeomanry (RMLY). The 3rd Dragoon Guards Raised by the Earl of Plymouth in response to Monmouth‚Äôs Rebellion in 1685, the 4th Horse were involved in Marlborough‚Äôs campaign during the War of the Spanish Succession and later took part in the battles of Blenheim, Oudenaarde and Malplaquet. In 1745 they were part of the force sent to Scotland to quell the rebellion led by the ‚ÄòYoung Pretender‚Äô. In 1747, they were renamed the 3rd Dragoon Guards and in 1765 received the Prince of Wales title and the right to wear his badge. They were involved in the French Revolutionary Wars and the Napoleonic Wars before serving at home, after which they were sent in 1858 to reinforce the Army in India. In 1883, they sent men to the Heavy Camel Corps in the Sudan. During the closing stages of the Boer War, they were used to round up Boe Commandos and by 1911 were back in Egypt ‚Äì where they suffered in a terrible Cholera outbreak. They fought in the trenches in the First World War ‚Äì suffering the highest casualties of any cavalry regiment and were remounted in 1918 in the breakthrough of the Hindenburg line. In 1922 they were amalgamated with the 6th Dragoon Guards (Carabiniers) to become the 3rd Carabaniers. Under this title they fought in the Second World War in Burma and took part in a renowned battle in their tanks at Numshigum. In 1971, they were again amalgamated with the Royal Scots Greys to become the Royal Scots Dragoon Guards. # The 5th Dragoon Guards Raised as Shrewsbury\‚Äôs Horse in 1685, with a troop raised by Sir Thomas Grosvenor in Chester, the Regiment joined Marlborough‚Äôs forces as the 6th Horse in 1702 and fought at Blenheim, Oudenaarde and Malplaquet . For most of the 18th century they were in the United Kingdom police and excise duties. In 1746 they were given the right to wear green facings ‚Äì the forerunner of today‚Äôs green trousers worn in No. 2 Dress (parade dress). In 1791, they were renamed the 5th Dragoon Guards. In the Napoleonic Wars, they fought at Beaumont and later spent 8 years in Liverpool, where they received the title of Princess Charlotte of Wale‚Äôs Own. They reinforced Wellington in the Peninsular Wars and in 1811 were involved at Salamanca. In 1854, in the Crimea, the Regiment was part of the successful charge at Balaklava, which saved the army supply depot. They spent the rest of the 19th century at home. As a result of service in the Boer War with the Regiment, Colonel Baden Powell formed the Scout Movement. They fought in the trenches in the First World War and in 1918 led the advance to the Bridgehead in Germany. In 1922 they were amalgamated with the 6th Inniskilling Dragoons to become the 5th Royal Inniskilling Dragoon Guards. In the Second World War the ‚ÄòSkins‚Äô as they were known fought from Normandy to the Elbe in tanks. After the War, they saw action in Korea and spent much of their post war service in British Amry of the Rhine. They were again amalgamated in 1992 with the 4/7th Dragoon Guards to become the Royal Dragoon Guards. Raising the Cheshires in 1689 The Cheshires were raised as an infantry regiment by Henry Duke of Norfolk, in March 1689. Extra troops were needed at the time to support William and Mary, when they accepted the crown from Parliament. The soldiers were recruited only a few hundred yards from here on the famous Roodee. Later, they became known as the 22nd (Cheshire) Regiment and they are still in active service today. Charles II‚Äôs orders of 1663, for the equipment of infantry still stood ‚Äì ‚Äú‚Ä¶each pikeman a sword and pike of 16 foot long and not under; and each musketeer a musket, with a collar of bandoliers, the barrels of which musket to be about four foot long and to contain bullet, fourteen of which shall weigh a pound weight‚Äù Leaving Dawpool on the Wirral they sailed to Ireland and took part in the siege of Carrickfergus under Marshal Schomberg. In 1690 on 1st July, they fought in the Battle of the Boyne where the Marshal (aged 80) was killed in a ‚Äòfriendly fire‚Äô incident. Regiments were 10 companies, each of 14 Pikemen, 46 Musketeers and 1 Company of Grenadiers. Regiments were 10 companies, each of 14 Pikemen, 46 Musketeers and 1 Company of Grenadiers. Raising the Cavalry Regiments ‚Äì 1685: On 5th May 1663, Charles II issued orders stating how his Army should be equipped. These orders stood for many years afterwards and were current when the cavalry regiments of this museum were formed in 1685. \‚ÄúEach horseman to have for his defence armes, back, breast and pot ‚Äì for his offensive armes, a sword and a case of pistols, the barrels whereof are no to be under fourteen inches in length\‚Äù. At the time regiments were known by their colonel‚Äôs name ‚Äì only in the 1740s did they become numbered according to their type. In 1685‚Ä¶ The 3rd Dragoon Guards were raised at the Earl of Plymouth\‚Äôs 4th Horse. The 5th Dragoon Guards were raised as the Early of Shrewsbury\‚Äôs 7th Horse. (The Earl of Shrewsbury was also Captain of the Bridgegate in Chester and his regiment was supplemented by a troop raised in Chester by Sur Thomas Grosvenor.) The 6th Dragoon Guards (who later became the Carabiniers as an honour) were raised as the 9th Horse. The 6th Inniskilling Dragoons were raised as Conyngham\‚Äôs Horse. 1685 ‚Äì Monmouth‚Äôs Rebellion followed by Judge Jefferies \‚ÄúBloody Assizes\‚Äù in the West Country. Raising of cavalry in Chester. 1688 ‚Äì James II heard Mass in the Agricola Tower Chapel. \‚ÄòGlorious Revolution\‚Äô brings Protestant William and Mary to the throne. 1689 ‚Äì Cheshire Regiment raised. 1690 ‚Äì Ban of England incorporated. 1692 ‚Äì Glencoe massacre in the Highlands. Regiments Of the 18th Century: The Cheshires spent the early part of the century in the expanding Empire Where they suffered many more Deaths from disease than through Battle. The cavalry fought with the Duke of Marlborough in the Wars of The Spanish Succession. The War of the Austrian Succession in 1743 saw the Regiments back in Europe. But in the middle of the Century troops were also an important force for law and Order in Britain - this was before the police were formed. The cavalry spent many years on garrison duty at home. The cheshires fought the French in the battle for Canada where their grenadiers became famous. Afterwards they fought for many years more in North America notably in the Cherokee wars. The Napoleonic Wars at the end of the century says regiments active in Europe again. The nearby war and revolution prompted formation of Provisional Cavalry Troops in 1797 from ‚Äòthe Gentlemen of Yeoman of the County‚Äô ‚Äì these became the Cheshire Yeomanry, who now join our story. 1707 1st Parliament of Great Britain Act of Union Passed by Scots Parliament. 1720 Purchase of Commissions began. 1726 Sir John Vanbrugh- Architect and dramatist and Chester resident died. 1740-48 War of Austrian Succession. 1742 Numbering of Regiments In the British Army‚Äôs Infantry began. 1745 ‚ÄúThe Forty-Five‚Äù Jacobite rebellion in Scotland under Bonnie Prince Charlie. 1758 Lord Amherst‚Äôs Expedition to Canada. 1761 Cherokee Wars. 1761 First Canals built-The Trent and Mersey across Cheshire. 1775-83 American Revolution. 1776 (July) American Declaration of Independence. 1780 Gordon Riots in England. 1785 Capt. North America: Louisbourg ‚Äì Louisbourg was a French stronghold in 1756, when the Seven Years War began. It was essential to the British in their quest for Canada. The 22nd Regiment sailed to America disembarking at Chester, Pennsylvania on 1st January 1757. In 1758 it formed part of the expedition led by Lord Amherst, which took Louisbourg fortress. The following year Louisbourg was used as a base in the conquest for Quebec. The 22nd took part in the Cherokee Wars of the 1760s from their American garrison and were part of the force which took Havanna in the 1761. American War of Independence ‚Äì 1775 to 1783. The 22nd was sent to Boston in 1775. It arrived too Late for the Batte of Bunker Hill Colonel Abercrombie (and his soldier servant) arrived ahead of the others and Fought in the battle. The Colonel was killed. A soldier‚Äôs Button found on the battlefield is on display. The Regiment had its main garrison in New York and Was engaged in many skirmishes in the Area. At the end of the war, when America became a republic, the 22nd returned home leaving all of their early records behind, and many of the men who deserted! The Death of Wolfe: The Grenadier Company of the Cheshire Regiment took part in the battle for Quebec, which was fought on the Heights of Abraham. Grenadiers were the largest men in a regiment and wore tall mitre caps and caried grenades with which they often led the attack. A grenade was a 2\"sphere of hollow iron containing gun powder. A fuse was lit just before it was thrown- using a slow burning match Ensign Henry Browne was close to General Wolfe, when he fell mortally wounded. It is said that the Ensign wrapped the General in the Regimental Colour and helped him from the battlefield. The bloodstained colour hung in Chester Cathedral until recently, a fragment is preserved on display here. Ensign Browne of the 22nd\'s Grenadier Company: wrote to his father. ‚Äú‚Ä¶our action of 13th September and the taking of the town of Quebec. I must add a little to it by informing you that I was the person who carried Gen Wolfe off the field and that he was wounded as he stood within a foot of me‚Ä¶‚Äù What was a Volunteer‚Äô in the Regular Army of the 18th Century? A Volunteer was a *gentleman‚Äô who did not have the money to Purchase a commission (or there were no suitable vacancies) so They served with the Rank and File awaiting their chance. He However, messed with the officers as a gentleman. James Henderson was a volunteer with the 22nd in Quebec. He Was in the Louisburg Grenadiers‚Äô, of which the 22nds‚Äôs Grenadier Company as part. Henderson was alongside General Wolfe when he sustained his third and fatal wound. In letter to His uncle, he claimed to have carried the stricken Wolfe to the Rear where he died in his arms. Dettingen And the oak leaves: The Battle of Dettingen was fought on 27th June 1743, in the War of the Austrian Succession, and it was the last time the army was Commanded by a British monarch. It was said That the mix of British steadfastness and the Hanoverian stubbornness in George II won the Day. He was a man who refused to be beaten. A detachment of the 22nd is believed to have taken part in the battle and to Have defended the King under an oak tree. He gave them the acorn and oak leaf Badge to wear. The regiment still has the acorn in its badge today and wears oak Leaves on certain regimental days, and always in the presence of royalty. The 3rd Dragoon Guards also took part. In Europe: The War of the Spanish Succession - 1702 to 1713 England, the Holy Roman Empire and the United Provinces of the Netherlands were engaged against France and Spain in the Wars of the Spanish Succession. This was a dispute over the Spanish throne after the death of Charles II of Spain, but worldwide interests in trade and the colonies were also at stake and the war raged for eleven years. The cavalry regiments won battle honours at Blenheim in 1704; Ramillies in 1706; Oudenarde in 1708 and at Tournai and Malplaquet in 1709. The war was finally resolved by the Treaty of Utrecht when the French Bourbon family secured the throne. The War of the Austrian Succession ‚Äì 1740 to 1748. The Cheshires and the 3rd Dragoon Guards fought in this conflict over the succession of the Habsburgs to their hereditary lands after the death of the Emperor Charles VI. War was waged in Bohemia, Upper Austria and Silesia. At the time the Cheshires were stationed in Minorca, from where detachments were sent to reinforce the British Army. Russia‚Äôs intervention fully let to peace negotiations and the Habsburgs retained all of their land except Silesia. Women of the Regiments: The wives of soldiers have usually followed their husbands. In the early days, women who travelled with the regiment were known as camp followers. Some even masqueraded as men to follow their loved ones and ‚Äòwent for a soldier‚Äô. The Famous Phoebe Hassel. Phoebe Hassel served as a soldier in the 5th Foot (the Royal Northumberland Fusiliers), throughout Marlborough‚Äôs campaigns. At the beginning of the 18th century. She was taken for a man throughout her service ‚Äì even when she was wounded and was only found to be a woman on her discharge. The King gave her a pension. On the strength It was usual for a limited number of wives to be allowed to travel with the regiment ‚Äì or ‚Äòon its strength‚Äô. This was usually 6, but in the case of the Cheshires was 8. The women acted as medical orderlies, served food and cleaned, for others as well as for their Husbands. Life was hard and they suffered all the privations of army Ife. When a husband was killed, the wife could marry another man within the regiment ‚Äì or return home. Finding wives abroad Many soldiers made marriages abroad. In the 1740s, while serving in Minorca, three young officers of the 22nd (George Kelly, Roger Schaak and Christopher French) persuaded three young nuns to marry them. All three travelled with the Regiment and the last of them Margarita French (n√©e Alberti) died in Dublin in 1797. Travelling with the family The habit of accompanying the regiments grew during the Victorian era. By 1860, when the 2nd Battalion 22nd was in Malta, there was a large contingent of family present and a Strong spirit of community, When the Birkby family died of Cholera, the regimental doctor and his wife adopted the surviving son. The boy was entrusted to the band aged 10 and finished his service as the bandmaster. Regiments of the 19th Century: The early part of the 19th century saw the regiments involved in campaigns against the French, and active in India. After the French wars ceased, they became increasingly involved in Zuri wars in the colonies ‚Äì most notably for The 22nd in India at the battles of Meeanee and Hyderabad in the Scinde. In 1854, the cavalry were involved in the Crimean War. The Second Burma War saw both battalions of the Cheshires involved. At home, the Cavalry and Yeomanry continued to be involved in upholding law and order, particularly in the earlier part of the century. In the muddle and later years there was an increase in the volunteer movement ‚Äì which swelled the ranks of the military. In the middle and later years there was an increase in the volunteer movement ‚Äì which swelled the ranks of the military. Napoleonic Wars ‚Äì 1800 to 1815: The Napoleonic Wars followed on from the French Revolutionary Wars. They were fought against France, who wished to maintain influence over the rest of Europe and her neighbours opposed to the Revolution. The wars were also fuelled by Napoleon‚Äôs personal ambition. After the first war in 1801, an uneasy peace prevailed for two years before hostilities broke out again and continued until 1815. The wars with France resulted in the newly formed Cheshire Yeomanry taking up garrison duties in Liverpool in 1805 so that regular regiments could go overseas. In 1810, Mauritius was taken from the French by the Cheshires, who were presented with a silver snuff box when leaving for being ‚Äòsuch good-natured conquerors.‚Äô This is now the oldest piece of regimental silver in the 1st Battalion‚Äôs collection. On the 18th February 1814, a second battalion of the 22nd (Cheshire) Regiment was formed to provide more men. It was disbanded after the Battle of Waterloo in 1815 when the French were finally defeated. The 6th Inniskilling Dragoons were part of the Union Brigade, which undertook a successful and victorious charge at Waterloo. At Home: Civil unrest about parliamentary reform led to a spate of riots in 1819. A huge gathering at St. Peter‚Äôs Fields in Manchester was forcibly broken up largely by the Manchester and Salford Yeomanry and 11 people died. These tragic events became known as the ‚ÄòPeterloo Massacre‚Äô in a sardonic reference to Waterloo. Although not directly involved, the Cheshire Yeomanry were present ‚Äì and were congratulated by the head of security forces for their ‚Äúgood bearing, steadiness and forbearance under provocation‚Äù ‚Ä¶ ‚ÄúWhat you did was right and gentle‚Äù Medicine in the Army
‚ÄòBiting the bullet‚Äô: \nOriginally surgeons were commissioned unto each regiment ‚Äì there was no Army Medical Service as there is today. The surgery methods were primitive and had changed little since Roman times. Essential tools were a sharp knife, a bone-saw and a bullet to bite on. The bullet was to avoid the patient shouting out with pain ‚Äì although a lucky man might receive a good shot of liquor as anaesthetic.\n \nThe Influence of Florence Nightingale: \nFlorence Nightingale and other medical pioneers in the Crimean War made great strides forward in the quality of care for wounded soldiers ‚Äì particularly in the area of hygiene. By the outbreak of the First World War, there was a Royal Army Medical Corps and each unit had trained stretcher-bearers. These men were sometimes \‚Äòconscientious objectors\‚Äô who served in \‚ÄòFriends\‚Äô Field Ambulances ‚Äì and many lost their lives trying to save others.\n \nTriage was invented in the First World War so that the seriously wounded, could be separated quickly from the walking wounded and the dead ‚Äì and those in the most need of effective treatment would receive it first. This system is still used in civilian Accident and Emergency Wards today.\n \nPreventative Medicine: \nAs treatment improved, the importance of preventative medicine became widely recognised. Cleanliness was a must ‚Äì Field Bath Units came into use and officers were issues with a canvas bath. Regular and dreaded foot inspections, by platoon officers took place. By the outbreak of the Second World War, inoculation was used to prevent soldiers contracting disease in foreign countries.\n \nEvacuation: \nMost recently not only has medicine improved (Plasma bottles are now carried in the field) but the ability to remove the wounded soldier quickly from the battlefield. Helicopters have been the real \‚Äòlife-saver\‚Äô here. Soldiers wounded in Northern Ireland have usually been treated within ten minutes of the incident. Standards, Guidons, Colours and Drum Banners - PLACEHOLDER: Armies have always used flags to identify themselves and to form rallying points for troops in battle. Standards: Horse Regiments and Dragoon Guards carry standards. They are small and square flags with regimental devices and battle honours embroidered onto them. Guidons: Dragoons, Light Dragoons, Hussars, Lancers and Yeomanry carry guidons. They are flags with tails. Colours: The infantry carry colours. These are larger banners ‚Äì usually two, a Queen\‚Äôs (or King\‚Äôs) Colour, and the Regiment\‚Äôs, which is based on its facing colour- in the case of the 22nd buff. All these types of flag were consecrated before they were presented to the Regiments. They are looked after carefully and treated with great reverence in honour of the men who served under them over the centuries. Cavalry Drum Banners: Traditionally the cavalry have used drum banners on their kettledrums with the battle honours and regimental badges on them. Plain issue copper drums were covered by the banner but if the regiment owned a silver drum, the banner was hung below it. The horse was originally a strong troop horse, but today is usually a shire. : Crimea: The war was fought in the Crimean Peninsula by Britain and France against Russia. (the first time that France had not been the enemy). The Russian successes in the Black Sea made the British and the French fearful that their further expansion into the Ottoman Empire would threaten overland routes to India and the Far East. Major battles were fought at the River Alma, Balaklava and Inkerman in 1854. In 1855, the fall of the Russian fortress at Sevastopol sealed their defeat and peace. Although the unsuccessful but heroic charge of the Light Brigade on the 25th October at Balaclava is very well known, it was the tremendous success of General Scarlett‚Äôs Heavy Brigade earlier on the same day, which saved the battle. The 5th Dragoon Guards and the 6th Inniskilling‚Äôs were part of the Heavy Brigade. A small Force of about 300 men caught several thousand Russian cavalry as they wheeled in a classic cavalry action. The impact put the Russians to flight. India and the Scinde campaign: The honourable East India Company controlled two thirds of the Indian sub-continent from their bases in Bombay, Madres and Calcutta. Between 1819 and 1849, several campaigns were taught to secure these territories in an attempt to expand them into Nepal, Burma and Afghanistan. These were largely successful except for the attempt on Afghanistan in 1842, which was fiercely resisted and resulted in defeat for the mixed British Indian force. The 44th Foot was virtually wiped out ‚Äì with the exception of one man who survived. The same year, the Cheshires moved to India and joined General Sir Charles Napier‚Äôs force to attack the Scinde. The rest of the small force was provided by the honourable East India Company (known as John Company‚Äôs troops).
